text: You didn’t wake me.
You were sleeping.
You let me sleep because you can’t bear to have breakfast with me. It’s half-serious. MICHAEL doesn’t react.
Nothing could be further from the truth. I boiled you an egg. See? MICHAEL produces a second boiled egg in a cup, seemingly nowhere, like a magician, and puts it on the table.
I’d hardly have boiled you an egg if I didn’t want to see you. Tea or coffee? BRIGITTE has re-appeared from the bedroom, now in a dress gown. She’s still half-serious.
Does any woman ever stay long enough to find out what the hell goes on in your head? MICHAEL smiles to himself.
What are you doing tonight?
I’m seeing my daughter.
Your daughter? You’ve kept very quiet about her.
Have I? She’s been abroad for a year. Did you say tea? INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. BERLIN. DAY MICHAEL kisses BRIGITTE on the cheek as she departs.

I’m going. Give my love to your daughter. He closes the door, then turns to the open door of the bedroom. He looks at the mess of last night’s love-making Then he goes to the window and looks out. A yellow U-Bahn goes by. INT. TRAM. DAY. December 1958. MICHAEL, now 15, is sitting on a tram. He in a well-cut suit he’s inherited, ill-fitting, with two- shoes and tangled mop of hair. Sweat breaks out all over face. A WOMAN is staring at him. He’s plainly feeling ill INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. DAY 1995. MICHAEL stands at the window, looking out.
1958. Impulsively MICHAEL gets up, rings the bell and get off at the next stop. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. DAY 1995. MICHAEL closes the window.

1958. It has come on to rain. MICHAEL is walking along th street, looking more and more sickly. There is an archway leading to a courtyard, and impulsively he darts inside t get out of the rain. He begins to vomit. Opposite him is wood workshop open to the yard. A uniformed TRAM CONDUCTR walks past. MICHAEL'S body is turned away, his face invisible, his h over his mouth. She puts down her ticket machine on the pavement and seizes him by the arm.

Hey. Hey! HANNA SCHMITZ has ash-blonde hair and is in her mid-thirt She disappears. He’s sick again. She reappears with a buc of water to sluice down the pavement. She wipes his face with a wet cloth. Then she fills another bucket.
Hey, kid. Hey.
I’m sorry. I’m sorry. Effortlessly, HANNA takes MICHAEL in her arms. She holds head against her breasts. MICHAEL buries himself and slow he stops sobbing. Then he lifts his head.
Where do you live?
HANNA and MICHAEL walk at a fair pace along a street, dot with the scaffolding of new building. HANNA is carrying h satchel, she is pulling him by the arm.
They come up the road. It is now snowing. MICHAEL stops outside his block, as if nervous she might come in.
It’s here. I’1ll be fine now. Thank you.

Look after yourself. MICHAEL smiles ‘Thank you’ and goes in. HANNA is left alo She looks round, frowning, then sets off, stopping uncertainly at the crossroads to check for the way she ca MICHAEL turns and watches, curious at her indecision.

CARLA BERG is at the stove in the kitchen. She takes dinn through for the BERG family, at a round table ina traditional apartment, under a five-candled brass chandel MICHAEL'S father, PETER, is a balding, abstracted man, e in oppressive silence. Next to him, his older brother THO 18, his older sister, ANGELA, and his younger sister, EMI MICHAEL has his book in front of him, not touching his fo
I’m worried about him. He looks terrible.
The boy’s saying he doesn’t need a doctor.
He does.
I don’t need a doctor.
Good then. CARLA looks reproachful.
Peter.
We’re not going to argue about this. People have to take responsibility for their own lives.
MICHAEL is lying in a single bed, his face violently inflamed. CARLA is with the DOCTOR, a much older man.
Remind me, how old are you now?
Michael’s fifteen.

It’s scarlet fever. He’ll be in bed for several months. At least. MICHAEL turns into the pillow, a wet patch beneath his he Delusional with fever, he senses a presence at the door. turns. It’s EMILY. But at once CARLA’s arm pulls her away
Keep away. He’s contagious. They vanish. The door closes. In the corridor the DOCTOR heard.
Burn the sheets. Complete isolation. And three months is the minimum.

1959. A sunny day in March. MICHAEL’s bed has been moved beside open windows so he can profit from the weak sun. H sitting up, working on his stamp collection. CARLA is mov round behind him, tidying the room.
How are you feeling?
Better. By the way, I meant to tell you, the day I got ill... a woman helped me. A woman in the street.
She helped you?
Yes. She brought me home.
Do you have her address?
MICHAEL is standing holding a small bunch of flowers. He looking puzzled at a row of bells with numbers only. The woodyard is busy. WORKMEN come out of the building.

MICHAEL comes up the stairwell, once grand, now in decay green linoleum and faded red paint. The sound of a sentimental song at the open door of a small apartment. Inside, HANNA is ironing in a sleeveless smock, blue with flowers. Her hair is fastened in a clip. She looks at him moment.

Come in.  INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY The flat is without decoration, an enfilade of small room stove, a sink, a tub, a boiler, a table, a few wooden cha There is no window, just a balcony door to let light into room. HANNA carries on ironing.
I brought you these flowers. To say thank you.

Put them down there. MICHAEL puts them beside the sink. HANNA has a blanket an cloth over the table : nothing disturbs her rhythm, as sh irons one piece of laundry after another, then folds it a puts it over one of the chairs.
I would have come earlier, but I’ve been in bed for three months.
You're better now?
Thank you.
Have you always been weak?

Oh no. I’d never been ill before. It’s incredibly boring. There's nothing to do. I couldn’t even be bothered to read. HANNA carries on ironing. He is becoming as comfortable w the silence as she is. She starts ironing a pair of knick He watches her bare arms moving back and forth. She looks broad-planed, strong. She is at peace with being watched. puts one pair of knickers down, then does another. Then s upends the iron.

I have to go to work. I’1l walk with you. Wait in the hall while I change. MICHAEL goes out into the hall. The kitchen door is sligh open. HANNA takes off her smock and stands in a green sli Her stockings are hanging over the back of a chair. She picks one up, rolls it, smooths it up over her calf knee, then attaches it to her suspender. She reaches for other. The flesh is bare between her legs. MICHAEL watche riveted. HANNA seems oblivious. But as she is about to pu the second stocking on, she looks at him. She drops her dress, and straightens, holding her stare. In response, h blushes, then panics and runs out of the flat. The door slams.
MICHAEL runs down the stairs in terror and shame, and out front door.
The WORKMEN look up, curious, as MICHAEL flies by, slammi the outer door.
MICHAEL is lying in bed. He looks up at the sound of a tr going by outside.
The tram making its way along the quiet street.
MICHAEL gets out of bed and quickly gets dressed.
MICHAEL, reading a book, watches unobserved, fascinated a HANNA collects tickets. She calls out the name of the nex stop. She doesn’t see him as she works.

MICHAEL is standing on the other side of the street from HANNA’S courtyard. He is in two minds about whether to go The WOODWORKERS are loading a van. He waits for them to finish before he slips in through the archway, making his to the stairs. INT. LANDING. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL is sitting on the steps of the first landing. The as if from nowhere, HANNA is suddenly standing behind him uniform, carrying a box of coal in one hand, a scuttle in other. She looks tired but not surprised to see him.
There are two more buckets downstairs. You can fill them and bring them up. HANNA walks straight past him. For a moment he tenses as there might be some contact. But she goes by.

MICHAEL opens the door. He turns on a dim light. There is flight of wooden stairs into the murk of a huge pile of c poured in from the street. He goes down to the bottom, an picks up a bucket. He digs in to the coke, and at once it comes tumbling down on him in a cloud of dust. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY HANNA is at the kitchen table, drinking a glass of milk. has taken off her jacket and loosened her tie. MICHAEL co in with the two buckets of coal, his face and clothes fil She roars with laughter, full-throated.
You look ridiculous, look at you, kid. MICHAEL sees himself in the mirror, but she has already g up, going towards the tub in the corner of the kitchen.
You can’t go home like that. Give me your clothes, I’1ll run you a bath. HANNA opens the tap. There’s a boiler, and steaming hot w comes out. MICHAEL takes off his sweater, then stops.
What, do you always take a bath in your trousers? HANNA takes his sweater and goes to open the balcony door undresses. She puts his sweater on the balcony rail.

It’s all right, I won’t look. On the contrary, she turns and walks straight towards him MICHAEL is naked. HANNA takes his clothes from the chair. gets into the bath. She goes to the balcony. In the bath, submerges himself. HANNA goes out and shakes his clothes in the open air.  When he comes up from under the water, she is laying his clothes back on the chair. She picks up the shampoo and h it to him.

Wash your hair, I‘1l get you a towel. MICHAEL washes his hair, then submerges again. When he co back up, HANNA is holding out a large towel. He gets out, turning away to hide his erection. From behind, she wraps body and rubs him dry. Then she lets the towel fall. She her body against his back, and he realises she’s naked. H turns and faces her.
So. That’s why you came back. MICHAEL looks at her, awed.
You’re so incredibly beautiful.

Now, kid, you know that’s not true. At once she puts her arms round him and they kiss. MICHAE goes down onto the floor, HANNA on top of him. All the ti she’s staring into his eyes. He can’t take it. He closes eyes and, about to come, begins to scream. She puts her h over his mouth to smother the noise.
