text: The family is half-way through their meal. MICHAEL is sit watching them eat, thinking about his lovemaking with HAN
You’ve inconvenienced your mother.
How many more times? I’ve said I’m sorry.
You scared her.

It’s hardly my fault, I got lost, that’s all. That’s why I was late. Can I have some more? He reaches for more stew. THOMAS goes on eating, a look o contempt on his face, too superior to engage in this.  10.
How can anyone get lost in their own home town?
The doctor told me I had to take walks.
So?
I meant to head for the castle, I ended up at the sports-field.
They’re in opposite directions.
It’s none of your business.
He’s lying.
He’s not lying. Michael never lies. CARLA smiles benignly. EMILY knows she’s right. They all on for a few moments.
Dad, I’ve decided, I want to go back to school tomorrow.
The doctor says you need another three weeks.
Well I’m going.
Peter?
If he wants to go back, then he must. MICHAEL can’t breathe, as if some decisive moment in his has been reached. PETER is looking at him, seeming to kno what’s going on.  11.
A massive brownstone building. The whole SCHOOL is coming out, but MICHAEL is first, in a desperate hurry, waving goodbye to his friends and running quickly away.

MICHAEL comes quickly up the stairs. The door of HANNA’S apartment is ajar. He pushes it open. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY HANNA is at the sink. MICHAEL comes in, precipitate, tear off his clothes and embracing her at the same time. He dr his trousers and lifts her onto the sink. He comes in abo twenty seconds. He stands sweating.
All right, kid, it’s not just about you.
They are on the bed. He is lying underneath her. HANNA le his hands to her face, then down her body. She begins to move, and in response, he moves too. He watches awed as s comes.
HANNA has fallen asleep on MICHAEL'S chest. He is awake, looking at the birthmark on her left shoulder. The sound the wood yard below. He kisses the birthmark. She stirs.
What’s your name? She opens her eyes. A look of suspicion.
What?
Your name.
Why do you want to know?
I’ve been here three times. You haven’t told me your name.  12. MICHAEL waits a moment.
It’s Hanna. What’s yours, kid?
Michael.
Michael. Hmm. So I’m with a Michael. HANNA smiles, as if there were something funny about it.
‘Hanna’.
A TEACHER, in his sixties, has scrawled the words ‘Odysse ‘Hamlet’ and ‘Faust’ on the blackboard. The class of BOYS attentive. Next to him, his friend HOLGER SCHLUTER. Acros the way, RUDOLF.

The notion of secrecy is central to Western literature. You may say the whole idea of character in fiction is defined by people holding specific information which for various reasons - sometimes perverse, sometimes noble - they are determined not to disclose. MICHAEL looks content. The bell goes.

The BOYS come pouring out cheerfully into the corridor an head to the next classroom. MICHAEL'S demeanour has chang There’s a knowingness, a swagger, a confidence which is n MICHAEL lingers for a moment, then slopes off in the oppo direction, alone.

MICHAEL comes out the back door of the school, unobserved climbs over the railings and starts to run down the stree INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. EVE Later. Dark. MICHAEL is almost asleep, HANNA awake.  13.
You never tell me what you've been studying.
Studying?
At school. Do you learn languages?
Yes.
What languages?
Latin.
Say something in Latin.
Oh... MICHAEL thinks a moment.
Quo, quo scelesti ruitis? Aut cur dexteris aptantur enses conditi? MICHAEL smiles slightly.
It’s Horace.
It’s wonderful.
Do you want some Greek? MICHAEL grins, pleased to be able to do something. He goe and gets his satchel. HANNA turns on a light.
Oi men ippeon stroton oi de pesedon oi da naon phais epi gan malainan emmenai kalliston, ego de ken otto tis eratai.
It’s beautiful.  14.
How can you tell? How do you know when you’ve no idea what it means? HANNA looks at him a moment.
What about in German?
In German?
Do you have anything?
Well, I’m writing an essay. It’s about a play. By a writer called Gotthold Ephraim Lessing. Perhaps you've heard of him? HANNA makes no reaction.
The play’s called Emilia Galotti.
Have you got it? MICHAEL reaches down to the satchel and pulls out a book.
Here. You can read it.
I’d rather listen to you. There is a silence as MICHAEL absorbs the idea.
All right. I’m not very good. MICHAEL grins, embarrassed, then opens the book.

Act One. Scene One. The setting one of the prince’s chambers. Prince - “Complaints, nothing but complaints, petitions, nothing but petitions. For goodness’ sake, just imagine that people actually envy us.”  15.
Later. They are in the bath together. HANNA takes a piece soap and runs it lovingly down his cheek. Then she passes soap across his stomach.
You’re good at it, aren’t you?
Good at what?
Reading. He smiles.
Why are you smiling?
Because I didn’t think I was good at anything.
MICHAEL is playing handball with terrific physical confidence. A couple of bruising physical encounters. HOL RUDOLF and MICHAEL all laugh. The whistle blows. Game ove
An empty tram moving through the eerie early morning stre MICHAEL appears walking alongside it and gets on.

MICHAEL is sitting in the second carriage. He looks up. T CONDUCTRESS is HANNA. At first, she does not notice him. MICHAEL watches, waiting to be noticed. She turns round a looks at him. He smiles in greeting but she makes no acknowledgement at all. She turns away. He frowns, bewildered.
The tram is heading out of town.
HANNA is now talking animatedly to the DRIVER. They are getting on very well, laughing together and chatting. MIC is still by himself in the second carriage, looking fooli  16.
The tram comes to a halt and PASSENGERS get on.

HANNA is now in the busy second carriage, collecting tick MICHAEL looks up expectantly. But as he holds up his tick HANNA makes no reaction except to clip it. She turns away without speaking. The tram comes to a halt again, and MICHAEL, humiliated, bolts for the door.

MICHAEL watches the tram disappears up the hill. He looks around, lost, in the middle of nowhere. A tractor goes by WORKERS heading to the fields. MICHAEL sets off to walk b to town. INT. LANDING. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL is on the stairs as HANNA comes up, in her unifor
What was all that about? HANNA lets herself in, saying nothing.
HANNA has gone in to put down her things at the kitchen table. MICHAEL follows, desperate.
I got up - at 4.30 - specially - it’s the first day of the holidays, I’d been planning to surprise you -
Poor little baby. Got up at four thirty - and on your holidays too.

What is this? I was on your tram! You totally ignored me! What do you think I was doing? Why the hell do you think I was there? MICHAEL has yelled in desperation. HANNA looks him straig in the eye.  17.
I haven't the slightest idea. And what you do is your business not mine. HANNA turns and moves away.
And if you wanted to speak to me, I was in the first carriage. So why did you sit in the second? HANNA goes to run a bath.
And now, thanks very much, I've been working, I need a bath. Get out, I’d like to be by myself.
I didn’t mean to upset you.

You don’t have the power to upset me. You don’t matter enough to upset me. She takes off her clothes to get in. As soon as she does, gets up and goes into the other room. He sits by himself, miserable. He hears her, bathing. Then finally gets up an goes back in. She is still in the bath.
I don’t know what to say. I’ve never been with a woman. We’ve been together four weeks and I can’t live without you. I can’t. Even the thought of it kills me. HANNA looks at him thoughtfully.
I sat in the second carriage because I thought you might kiss me.
Kid, you thought we could make love in a tram? They smile. But MICHAEL has a more urgent question.  18.
Is it true what you said? That I don’t matter to you? In the bath, she shakes her head.
Do you forgive me? She nods.
Do you love me? She looks at him. Then she nods. INT. BEDROOM. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL is sitting on the side of the bed. HANNA comes in wrapped in a towel.
Do you have a book?
Oh. Well I do. I took something with me this morning.
What is it?
It’s another play. MICHAEL gets it out of his pocket. HANNA has lain down on bed, completely content.
We're changing the order we do things. Read to me first, kid. Then we make love. MICHAEL sits at the foot of the bed and starts to read.
Intrigue and Love, a play by Friedrich Schiller... INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY HANNA is baking bread. MICHAEL is on a chair beside her w a book.  He starts 19.
The Odyssey by Homer.
What’s an odyssey?
It’s a journey. He sets out on a journey. to read.

“Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy. Many cities of men he saw and learned their minds, Many pains he suffered, heartsick at the open sea, Fighting to save his life and bring his comrades home... INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. EVE HANNA is in the bath. MICHAEL is reading a Shakespeare so to her. She pulls
“And we will some new pleasures prove of golden sands and crystal brooks, with silken lights and silver hooks...”
Come here. him into the bath. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. NIGHT HANNA is sewing. MICHAEL is reading Huckleberry Finn.

I poked into the place aways and encountered a little open patch as big as a bedroom, all hung around with vines and found a man lying there asleep, and by Jinks it was my old Jim...  20. He starts acting out Jim, and the two of them collapse laughing. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL is at the bottom of the bed. HANNA is lying insid He is reading Lady Chatterley’s Lover.
“Lady Chatterley felt his naked flesh against her as he came into her. For a moment he was still inside her...
This is disgusting. Where did you get this?
I borrowed it from someone at school.
You should be ashamed. Go on. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL reads Tin-Tin to HANNA, who is lying on the bed. are both looking at the pictures.
‘Blistering Barnacles and a thundering typhoon. It is water.’ ‘But what on earth did you expect it to be?’
Whisky.
Whisky! By thunder, whisky. ‘Whisky? Come now captain, you can’t be serious.’
All right, kid, that’s enough for today. They fall back onto the bed.  21.
I was wondering, do you think you could get some time off? Maybe we could go for a trip.
What sort of trip?
I’d love to go bicycling. Just for two days. MICHAEL reaches for a book.
I’ve got a guide-book. I’ve worked out the route. Look, what do you think? HANNA’S look is so far-away she doesn’t seem to hear the question. Silence. Then :
I think you like planning, don’t you? She throws the book away and they begin to make love.

First light. Dawn breaking outside the window. MICHAEL is working at his desk, the surface covered in stamps, his collection book open. He picks one with a pyramid on it a looks at it. Underneath, MICHAEL'S VOICE reading Intrigue Love by Schiller.

“I'm not frightened. I’m not frightened of anything. Why should I be? I welcome obstacles, because they’1l be like mountains I can fly over to be in your arms. The more I suffer, the more I’1l love...

Seen from outside, a shop full of stamps. MICHAEL and a S DEALER with white hair and a moustache. MICHAEL is offeri his pyramid stamp, his gestures becoming desperate as the STAMP DEALER shakes his head, clearly not giving him as m as he hopes.  22. Then MICHAEL concedes, the DEALER concedes, and a bunch o notes are handed across. MICHAEL runs exhilarated out int the street.

“Danger will only increase my love, it will sharpen it, it will give it spice. I’ll be the only angel you need. On this arm, Luise, you will go dancing through life. You will leave life even more beautiful than you entered it. Heaven will take you back and look at you and say ‘Only one thing can make a soul complete, and that thing is love.’
HANNA and MICHAEL are whizzing down a hill together on bicycles. He has a rucksack. It’s a rural paradise - hill all sides, a gleaming river below, the sun shining bright She is wearing a blue dress.
They come to a cafe and sit down outside. They pick up th menus on the table. A WAITRESS arrives.
So what would you like to have?
What are you having?
You order. I'll have what you have. MICHAEL starts giving the order. Next to them are a group BOY SCOUTS, who are laughing among themselves.
There’s sausages, sausages or sausages. Give it to me, come on, give it here. Let me have a look. You always have the same thing. They all laugh. HANNA watches them nervously.
The meal finished, MICHAEL is alone, paying the bill.
I hope your mother was happy.  23.

Thank you. She enjoyed her meal very much. The WAITRESS goes. HANNA returns from inside. MICHAEL hol out his arm to her, which she takes. They walk away towar their bikes. He is smiling. MICHAEL looks round, then dar to reach across and kiss her on the lips. The WAITRESS watches.
They get off their bikes at a small church. MICHAEL stops gets out a map and a guide book.
Here, let me show you where we’re going.
It’s OK, kid. I don’t want to know. The sound of a choir from inside.

MICHAEL and HANNA enter tentatively to find a choir rehearsing Bach. It is a traditional German scene - whole families singing together at the altar. HANNA is transpor entranced at the sound of the music. MICHAEL watches.
HANNA is in a river, the water up to her calves, her skir tied round her thighs. She is completely absorbed. Then s looks up, aware of being watched. MICHAEL is sitting with notebook.
What are you doing?
I’m writing a poem. About you.
Can I hear it?
It’s not ready. I'll read it to you one day.  24.

1995. MICHAEL, now 51, is standing by his desk. He opens drawer. He takes out the recognizable notebook. He opens yellowing pages and looks at the poetry. Then flips the pages, to some handwritten lists - the words ‘Odyssey’, ‘Schnitzler’, ‘Chekhov’, ‘Zweig’ with numbers beside them MICHAEL flaps it shut, puts it back and turns to go out.
MICHAEL leaves his apartment block. He gets into his blac Mercedes.

MICHAEL is listening on the radio to the same Bach music heard in the church. He drives through the thriving moder city. Beyond, the huge cranes and gouged-out building sit of a city under construction.
MICHAEL swings his car into place. He gets out and heads across the road, prosperous, purposeful.
An ASSISTANT meets MICHAEL with his robe which he pulls o he walks quickly through an elaborate lobby. GERHARD BADE also in his fifties, also robed, falls in step.
You all right, Michael?
I’m fine.
You'd better hurry. You know what she’s like. A robed ASSISTANT is waiting outside the door with docume he hands to MICHAEL. They all go in.

MICHAEL joins his CLIENT, just seconds before the FEMALE JUDGE comes in and everyone stands. Silence. The JUDGE lo at MICHAEL disapprovingly, sensing his lateness. Everyone sits. MICHAEL sits, thinking back.  25.
1958. A sheriff's posse of sixteen-year old GIRLS, come laughing, blushing towards the classroom. One of them is talking excitedly to the other.
I’m just going to pretend I’ve been here for years, I’m not going to behave in any special way.
You just wait. You wait and see. They smile together and head for the classroom.
The BOYS are already in place, dotted round, as the GIRLS come in. There are cries of ‘Here they come’. Then the TEACHER comes in.

Good morning, ladies. Gentlemen, please welcome your new fellow- students, treat them with courtesy, please. Not far from MICHAEL, a GIRL sits across the aisle, virgi with brown hair, brown summer skin.
Hello. My name’s Sophie.
I’m Michael. The TEACHER comes in. The class quietens.
Later. The TEACHER is in full flow. MICHAEL can’t take hi eyes off SOPHIE.
Everyone believes that Homer’s subject is homecoming. In fact, The Odyssey is a book about a journey. Home is a place you dream of, it’s not a place you ever attain. The TEACHER breaks off.  26.
Berg, I don’t mean to distract you, but we’re meant to studying Homer, not studying Sophia. The whole class cracks up. MICHAEL blushes.

MICHAEL is riveted as SOPHIE swims fast and lithe through water. Around him, YOUNG PEOPLE are lounging round on tow It’s the social centre. HOLGER and RUDOLF are rubbing the hair with towels as SOPHIE approaches.
Michael the water’s fantastic.
It’s wonderful, isn’t it?
Wonderful. It’s going to be a great summer. MICHAEL looks across to where a group of AMERICANS are shouting and playing a very loud game of volleyball.
Now the Americans have allowed us back in our own lake.
Why are they so loud?
You should see their stores. They have everything.
Oh sure. Everything mankind could ever dream of.
You don’t like Americans?

Just it’s more fun without them. He looks SOPHIE straight in the eye. There is a sudden silence, MICHAEL looking straight at SOPHIE. SOPHIE looks down. Then MICHAEL moves slightly to pack up his stuff.  27.
Why do you leave early?
He always leaves early.
MICHAEL is cycling back towards town, a smile on his face
MICHAEL flies up the stairs, then goes in. HANNA is sitti sewing. He kisses her on the cheek as he gets out a book.
I’m sorry I’m late. I was held up at school. At once he sits down opposite her. A ritual.
The Lady with the Little Dog. By Anton Chekhov. HANNA looks, seeing right through him.
“The talk was that a new face had appeared on the promenade, a lady with a little dog.”
A huge tram-shed full of empty trams. HANNA is at the end the garage, talking to the SUPERVISER, a large man in his fifties.

Schmitz, one moment. We’ve got good news for you. Your work is good, we're going to promote you. To work with me in the office. It’s more money. Congratulations. He moves away. HANNA looks distraught.
MICHAEL is watching SOPHIE swimming, a look of anxiety in eye, when HOLGER touches his shoulder.  28.
Get a move on, we’re leaving early today.
Why? What for?
We're going back to Sophie's. It’s your birthday. We’re giving you a party. HOLGER and RUDOLF disappear to get dressed. SOPHIE appear her swimming costume.
Come on, it’s a surprise. We thought you’d like it. We’ve been planning it for weeks.
I’m sorry. Really. I promised someone I’d do something else. The others are furious with him. They all go off.

MICHAEL is cycling towards HANNA’S apartment, his hair we from the lake, looking equally unhappy. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY HANNA is sitting unhappily as MICHAEL reads to her. They both in a bad mood.
Oh kid, kid. Stop.
What’s wrong?
Nothing’s wrong. It’s nothing. HANNA just shrugs. She goes and sits at the table to drin tea. MICHAEL is irritated.
You never ask, you never bother to ask how I am.  29.
You never say.
It just happens to be my birthday. It’s my birthday, that’s all. In fact, you've never even asked when it is.
Look if you want a fight, kid...
No, I don’t want a fight. What’s wrong with you?
What business is it of yours? She has snapped at him, razor-like.
It’s always on your terms. Everything. We do what you want. It’s always what you want. My friends were giving me a party!

Well then why are you here? Go back to your party. Isn’t that what you want? HANNA puts down her cup, angry. She goes into the bedroom slams the door. He sits, the magic of the day gone. He ge up and opens the bedroom door. HANNA is on the bed.
And it’s always me that has to apologize. Silence. HANNA lets time go by. Then
You don’t have to apologize. No-one has to apologize. No-one can make you. HANNA reaches for a book from beside the bed. She throws down on the cover.

War and Peace, kid.  30. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY HANNA is on the edge of the bath, running water. She has pale blue flowered smock. She is running with sweat. The smock sticks to her. MICHAEL gets out a book. HANNA drops lavender oil into the bath. MICHAEL stands in the bath an she washes his body. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY They are making love on the bed. It’s intense. At one poi she moves on top of him. She holds his head between her hands, as if she would crush the life out of him. Then sh lets go.
They are both sweating, exhausted. She looks a moment.

Now you must go back to your friends. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL has gone. HANNA washes out milk bottles and empti them into the sink. Then she picks up her luggage and lea the empty apartment.

MICHAEL is sitting on the pier watching as HOLGER, RUDOLF SOPHIE swim competitively out to a pontoon, then turn bac full of energy and high spirits. MICHAEL watches for a wh then suddenly he gets up and starts to run away from them all.

Michael. You all right? But MICHAEL is running away across the lakeside beach. INT. LANDING & HANNA’S APARTMENT. DUSK MICHAEL opens the door. He goes in. The apartment is empt the rented furniture in place, all trace of HANNA gone. H looks round. He looks at the empty bath, the tap above it opens the kitchen cupboards - some coffee, sugar, that’s about it. He goes into the bedroom, the bed stripped bare lies down on the bed.  31. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. NIGHT MICHAEL lying on the bed, curled up, in his clothes, like foetus, asleep.
The family at breakfast. MICHAEL slips quietly in the mai door, trying to go to his room without being heard. EMILY runs to look.
It’s him. Sheepishly MICHAEL appears.
Where were you last night? What happened?
I stayed at a friend’s.
Carla. PETER looks. He seems to know exactly what’s been going o
Get the boy something to eat. I think we all knew you’d come back to us eventually.
MICHAEL is alone in the deserted pool. He is on the jetty takes off his clothes and slips into the water. Just his head, like a seal’s, at one end, just out of the water, q still.
1995. MICHAEL sitting alone, thinking back.
1958. The sun slants, and for a few seconds the water dazzles. He slips his head under.
1995. MICHAEL still sitting thoughtfully by himself in th empty court. Then he looks up. An ASSISTANT has appeared.  32.
Mr Berg. It is eight o’clock. Your daughter.
Thank you. He gets up.
JULIA is already at the table in a chic modern brasserie. is a sympathetic young woman of around 23. MICHAEL approaches. When she sees him, she gets up.
I was early. MICHAEL leans in and kisses her on the cheek.
Julia. They’re uneasy. She looks a moment, then they sit down.
Welcome back.
Later. They have eaten. They both have big glasses of red wine. It’s more relaxed.
So how will you decide?
I don’t know. I’m happy back in Berlin, I suppose.
You've seen your mother? JULIA nods.
I wanted to get away. There was nothing more to it. It was Paris, but it could have been anywhere.
Away from your parents?  33. JULIA doesn’t answer.
I’m aware I was difficult. I wasn’t always open with you. I’m not open with anyone.
I knew you were distant. I'd always assumed it was my fault.
Julia. How wrong can you be? JULIA colours, on the verge of tears. Then she looks away
They drive through the gleaming streets. It’s been rainin Berlin is glistening. Their voices :
I admit it now, I was nervous.
I was nervous too. It’s silly isn’t it?
It is silly.
Thank you for dinner.
I’ll see you very soon.
MICHAEL lets JULIA out, and is watching her safely to her door from the car.
Good night, Dad. MICHAEL suddenly gets out himself.
Julia, wait. I want to ask you a favour.
What favour?  34.
I want to take you on a trip. I want to show you something.
When?
Tomorrow, maybe. Can I pick you up in the car? JULIA doesn’t need to say anything.
At ten, say. JULIA smiles.

Then good. MICHAEL hugs her, his heart aching with love. JULIA goes to her place. MICHAEL is left standing still in the plaza outside, not moving. Underneath the sound of what follows thirty years previously.

head_text.subj: INT. LECTURE ROOM. HEIDELBERG LAW SCHOOL. DAY

text: 1966. A WOMAN LECTURER has a class of about 75 STUDENTS. their hair, their dress, it could only be the 1960s.

Those of you for the special seminar group on The Legal System in the Third Reich, please stay on in this room. Professor Rohl will be here in a moment. Nearly all the STUDENTS leave, talking among themselves. eight are left, dotted around the huge room. MICHAEL is o of them, now 22, in a corduroy jacket and tie. There is a lull. MICHAEL looks round at the group of oddballs, then finds ROHL, distinguished, greying, is already in front o them.

Well, we seem to be quite a small group. A small group and a select one. Clearly, this is going to be a unique seminar. Let me start by thanking those of you who’ve chosen to take part. Good for you. A reading list, gentlemen. (MORE )
ROHL (cont'd) Karl Jaspers, The Question of German Guilt... A calm STUDENT with long hair smiles at MICHAEL. She look like Francoise Hardy. She murmurs.
And ladies.
MICHAEL is working alone at his desk, a light on. The doo his extremely modest student digs is open. MARTHE appears the door, silently. He looks up.
So this is where you are.
Yes. Come in. But neither of them move. MARTHE just smiles from the doo
You take work seriously.
Oh I don’t know.
You’re rather a serious boy. MARTHE shrugs slightly.
It’s how I was brought up. What about you? Are you serious?
You’re sure you want to work tonight?
Well I do. But I won’t work every night.
See you tomorrow. They smile at one another. She goes.  36.
The seminar group, long-haired, hippyish, is on the train PROFESSOR ROHL, with MARTHE, DIETER and a few others. MIC catches MARTHA’S eye. They smile. Then he opens the windo cheerful.

The STUDENTS are having a cigarette in front of the huge building. Two black vans with barred windows come by, carrying prisoners. The first one veers close to MICHAEL the pavement, then disappears into the inner courtyard. R smiles at MICHAEL.
Why all the police?
They’re worried about demonstrators.
For or against?
Both.

A courtroom has been improvised inside the town hall. The are large windows, with milky glass, down the left-hand s As ROHL and the STUDENTS arrive, the court is a melee of PHOTOGRAPHERS, LAWYERS and PUBLIC. The three JUDGES are already in place, next to six selected CITIZENS. MICHAEL the others take places in the gallery
All photographers are now asked to leave. The PHOTOGRAPHERS go.
The defendants, please. From being noisy and chaotic, the court is now silent.
The first thing I’m going to do is hear motions from each of the defendants’ lawyers. (MORE )
JUDGE (cont'd) They’re going to be arguing that there’s no reason to keep the defendants in jail until the outcome of the forthcoming trial. DIETER grins at MICHAEL in anticipation.
I am going to take these cases one by one. MICHAEL is leaning down to get stuff out of his briefcase MARTHE shakes a pen which isn’t working.
Do you want a pen?
I’ve got a pen. So MICHAEL doesn’t hear as the JUDGE speaks.

Hanna Schmitz. There is a row of six DEFENDANTS. The fifth woman is HANN her hair tied in a knot, her gaze fixedly into the middle distance, not looking towards the SPECTATORS. She is wear a grey dress with short sleeves. They all sit, sideways t the gallery. HANNA rises to her feet. The words seem to c very quietly, across a great distance.
Your name is Hanna Schmitz?
Yes. It is only when the JUDGE repeats the name that MICHAEL l up, hearing it for the first time.
Can you speak louder please?
My name is Hanna Schmitz. MICHAEL is rigid, blank, just staring.
Thank you. You were born on October 21st, 1922?  38.
Yes.
At Hermannstadt. And you’re now 43 years old?
Yes.
You joined the SS in 1943?
Yes.
What was your reason? What was your reason for joining? HANNA doesn’t answer.
You were working at the Siemens factory at the time?
Yes.
You'd recently been offered a promotion. Why did you prefer to join the Ss? HANNA has a DEFENCE COUNSEL, a young man, beside her, who about to get up. But the JUDGE forestalls him.
I’ll re-phrase my question. I’m trying to ascertain if she joined the SS freely. Of her own free will. Everyone waits.
Well?
I heard there were jobs.
Go on.  39.
I was working at Siemens when I heard the SS was recruiting.
Did you know the kind of work you'd be expected to do?
They were looking for guards. I applied for a job. MICHAEL is intent now, so are the STUDENTS beside him.
And you worked first at Auschwitz?
Yes.
Until 1944. Then you were moved to a smaller camp near Cracow?
Yes. ROHL leans into MICHAEL.
Are you OK?
I’m fine.
You then helped move the prisoners west in the winter of 1944 in the so-called death marches?
MICHAEL is hanging out of the window of the train, smokin cigarette.
MICHAEL sits down in his seat. ROHL moves to sit opposite him.
So what did you think?  40.
I don’t know. It wasn’t quite what I expecting.
Wasn’t it? In what way? What were you expecting? ROHL is looking at him. MICHAEL doesn’t answer.
I thought it was exciting.
Exciting?
Yes.
Why? Why did you think it exciting?
Because it’s justice.
The train hurtles through the German countryside.

A student party, in a candle-lit room. MARTHE is singing guitar. It’s been going on for hours - the STUDENTS are o the floor with beer and cigarettes. The front door is ope DIETER, beer in hand, looks out to the balcony where he c see MICHAEL bent away from them, all by himself.
MICHAEL, his arms on the balcony, is smoking, looking out into the night. His eye lands on a student room in which couple are making love.

head_text.subj: INT. LECTURE ROOM. HEIDELBERG LAW SCHOOL. DAY

text: The small STUDENT GROUP is now rattling around informally the big lecture room.
I need to correct an impression. Dieter said yesterday this was about justice. But is it? (MORE )

ROHL (cont'd) If it were about justice you might ask why has it taken so long? The war ended twenty years ago. Remember, there’ve been no significant trials between Nuremburg in 1946 and the Auschwitz trials a couple of years ago. That’s a long gap. What’s the reason for the gap? ROHL waits a moment for a STUDENT to answer.
I’d have thought it was obvious.
Say.
Cowardice. It’s cowardice, isn’t it? It’s bad conscience. It’s the big cover-up.
Go on.
After the war. The German people didn’t want to look at what they’d done.
Is that right?
Because they had too much to hide. All our parents are liars. All right, mine are. So it’s left to us, isn’t it?
How so?
Because we're not implicated.
Aren’t you? Good. So that’s all right then. Everyone laughs.  42.

No, but seriously, Dieter’s right. My parents, I can’t even talk to them. I don’t love them. How could I? How could anyone love them? Because they’ve told themselves so many lies, they can’t remember the truth, let alone admit it. Isn’t that why we signed up for this seminar?
I don’t know. You tell me.
Speaking for myself.
Michael?
I’m not sure any more. ROHL is staring at him thoughtfully.
What did your father do, Dieter?
If you want to know, he was in the Waffen SS. There are some smiles, but DIETER rides over the reaction
That’s what I mean, that’s what I’m saying. So were a million other Germans.

That’s exactly my point. That’s why it’s better not to pretend this is about justice. Forgive me, nor is it about getting into an emotional state. It has no purpose if it’s just the young giving their parents a bad time. There’s a silence. That’s clearly why some of them are th
So what is it about? What do you think?  43.

Societies think they operate by something called morality. But they don’t. They operate by something called law. You’re not guilty of anything merely by working at Auschwitz. 8,000 people worked at Auschwitz. Precisely 19 have been convicted, and only 6 for murder. To prove murder you have to prove intent. That’s the law. Remember, the question is never ‘Was it wrong?’ but ‘Was it legal?’ And not by our laws, no, by the laws at the time. DIETER frowns, unhappy.
But isn’t that...
What?
Narrow?
Yes. The law is narrow. ROHL looks unapologetic.
On the other hand, I suspect people who kill other people tend to be aware that it’s wrong.
ROHL is leaning forward, attentive. HANNA is standing, opposite the JUDGE, who holds up a book called MOTHER & DAUGHTER : A STORY OF SURVIVAL.
Miss Schmitz, you're familiar with this book...
Yes...
Parts of it have already been read out in court. (MORE )
JUDGE (cont'd) It’s an American publication, which has been translated. It’s by a survivor, a prisoner who survived, Ilana Mather...
Yes I know. I know Ilana Mather.
She was in the camp, wasn’t she, when she was a child? She was with her mother. The judge waits. HANNA seems arrogant, defiant.

In the book, she describes a selection process. At the end of the month’s labour, every month, sixty inmates were selected. They were picked out to be sent from the satellite camp back to Auschwitz. That’s right, isn’t it?
Yes, it’s right.
And so far, each of your fellow defendants has specifically denied being part of that process. Now I’m going to ask you. Were you part of it?
Yes. There is a stir among the other DEFENDANTS and in the cou They start talking to their LAWYERS.
So you helped make the selection?
Yes.
You admit that? Then tell me, how did that selection happen? HANNA shrugs slightly, as though it were obvious.  45.
There were six guards, so we decided we'd choose ten people each. That's how we did it - every month. We’d all choose ten.
Are you saying your fellow defendants took part in the process?
We all did.
Even though they’ve denied it? But you admit it. You’re saying you took part in the process. The other DEFENDANTS stir with animosity, but the JUDGE i intent, following his own line. He waits.
Did you not realise you were sending these women to their deaths? HANNA nods slightly.
Yes but there were new arrivals, new women were arriving all the time, so of course we had to move some of the old ones on.
I’m not sure you understand...
We couldn’t keep everyone. There wasn’t room. The JUDGE frowns, genuinely surprised that she doesn’t se to understand his point.
No, but what I’m saying : let me rephrase : to make room, you were picking women out and saying ‘You you and you have to be sent back to be killed.’  46.

Well, what would you have done? HANNA is looking at the JUDGE - a perfectly straight question. MICHAEL smiles slightly, proud of her. Everyone the court waits for the JUDGE to answer. Silence. ROHL is impassive. But HANNA follows her own thoughts. She quietl asks herself a question.
So should I never have signed up at Siemens?

MICHAEL is alone, smoking. On a bench, side by side, are women. One is very small, dark, in her sixties. The other composed, formidable, elegant, in her thirties. ROSE and ILANA MATHER. They look up, catching MICHAEL’s eye. Then CLERK leans in to the younger woman.
Ms. Mather, they’re ready for you now. The two women go into the court. The door closes.

MICHAEL is alone in the now-deserted lobby, unwilling to back. Then he goes to the door. He opens it a little. The sound of the trial. He opens the door fully. MICHAEL can that it is ILANA who is testifying. The court is conspicuously packed. Large black-and-white photographs o the labour camp now dominate the room. MICHAEL comes quie into the back of the room as the trial goes on. MICHAEL has pushed past a couple of people to sit down ne ROSE who is sitting in the body of the court. He looks ac to the DEFENDANTS. RITA BECKHART, a large older woman, is of a couple who isn’t bothering to listen.
In your book you describe the process of selection...
Yes. You were made to work and then, when you were no longer any use to them, then they sent you back to Auschwitz to be killed.  47.
Are there people here today who made that selection?
Yes.
I need you to identify them. Can you please point them out? ILANA points with her finger at the DEFENDANTS.
Her. And her. And her. And her. And her. And her. The last finger has been to HANNA. MICHAEL watches, but H does not react.
Each of the guards would choose a certain number of women. Hanna Schmitz chose differently.
In what way differently?

She had favourites. Girls, mostly young. We all remarked on it, she gave them food and places to sleep. In the evening, she asked them to join her. We all thought - well, you can imagine what we thought. HANNA stares back, impassive. MICHAEL watches.

Then we found out - she was making these women read aloud to her. They were reading to her. At first we thought this guard, this guard is more sensitive, she's more human, she's kinder. Often she chose the weak, the sick, she picked them out, she seemed to be protecting them almost. But then she dispatched them. Is that kinder? HANNA looks back, not apologizing.  48.
MICHAEL sits alone, head in hands, in despair.
Now ROSE is testifying. The court is quiet, focused.
I want to move on now to the march. As I understand it, you and your daughter were marched for many months.

Yes. It was the winter of 1944. Our camp was closed down, we were told we had to move on. But the plan kept changing every day. Women were dying all around us in the snow. Half of us died on the march. My daughter says in the book, less a death march, more a death gallop. MICHAEL looks along the row to where ILANA is now sitting

Please tell us about the night in the church. MICHAEL watches as ROSE looks across to ILANA. ILANA star back at her. MICHAEL watches the exchange as ROSE nods, a accepting she must go ahead and speak.

That night we actually thought we were lucky because we had a roof over our heads. We’d arrived ina village, as always, the guards took the best quarters, they took the priest’s house. But they let us sleep in a church. There was a bombing raid. In the middle of the night. At first we could only hear the fire, it was in the steeple. Then we could see burning beams, and they began to crash to the floor. Everyone rushed, rushed to the doors. But the doors had been locked on the outside.  49.
The church burned down? Nobody came to open the doors? Is that right?
Nobody.
Even though you were all burning to death? ROSE nods.
How many people were killed?
Everyone was killed.
How did you survive?

I needed to get away from the other women. Because they were panicking, they were screaming. I couldn't stand it. I couldn’t stand their screaming. I was more frightened of the other women than I was of the fire. So I too my daughter and led her to the upper floor. I can’t defend what I did. It’s impossible to defend. I took Ilana in my arms and I led her towards the fire. There was a small gallery at the side of the church on the upper level. It saved our lives. The gallery didn’t burn. ROSE turns, in tears, to look at ILANA.
Thank you. I want to thank you for coming to this country today to testify.

head_text.subj: INT. LECTURE ROOM. LAW SCHOOL. DAY

text: The group is back in the big hall. But the atmosphere is grim. It’s a while before DIETER speaks.  50.
I don’t know. I don’t know what we're doing any more.
Don’t you?
You keep telling us to think like lawyers, but there’s something disgusting about this. ROHL is very still, like an analyst who is finally leadin his patient to the heart of things.
How so?
This didn’t happen to the Germans. It happened to the Jews. Everyone is shocked at his violent passion.
What are we trying to do?
We're trying to understand.
Six women locked three hundred Jews in a church, and let them burn. What is there to understand? Tell me, I’m asking : what is there to understand? MICHAEL can’t answer. DIETER gets up, outraged now.
I started out believing in this trial, I thought it was great, now I think it’s just a diversion.
Yes? Diversion from what?
You choose six women, you put them on trial, you say ‘They were the evil ones, they were the guilty ones’. Brilliant! (MORE )
DIETER (cont'd) Because one of the victims happened to write a book! That’s why they’re on trial and nobody else. Do you know how many camps there were in Europe? DIETER turns, furious.

People go on about how much did everyone know? ‘Who knew?’ ‘What did they know?’ That isn’t the question. The question is ‘How could you let it happen?’ And - better - ‘Why didn’t you kill yourself when you found out?’ One of the group walks out.
Thousands! That’s how many. There were thousands of camps. Everyone knew. DIETER’S passion is so great that everyone is shaken.
Look at that woman...
Which woman?
The woman you’re always staring at. I’m sorry but you are. MICHAEL is white. The atmosphere is electric.
I don’t know which woman you mean.
You know what I’d do? Put the gun in my hand, I’d shoot her myself.
MICHAEL walks along an empty wooded road, miles from anywhere. The sun is shining through the trees behind him  52.
The wire fence of a concentration camp, deserted. MICHAEL with a back-pack, goes alone through the metal gate. MICH walks among the deserted empty huts.

Inside one of the huts, MICHAEL is by himself staring at line of empty beds. He moves on, overwhelmed, lost. He pa through the showers. Then he comes to a room with vast me cages on either side. In the cages, the countless dusty s of the exterminated.
MICHAEL opens a door and walks into a room with a line of ovens. He walks past them. Then he stands beside them, hi head down.
HANNA is standing being examined by the JUDGE. Large photographs and maps of the village, with the lay-out of church, are now on display.
Why did you not unlock the doors? He waits. HANNA doesn’t reply.
Why did you not unlock the doors? The JUDGE turns to the row of DEFENDANTS.

I’ve asked all of you and I’m getting no answer. Two of the victims are in this court. They deserve an answer. ILANA and ROSE are not far away from MICHAEL and the STUDENTS. The JUDGE puts down a bound handwritten documen
Here, this is the SS report. You all have copies. There is a flurry of paperwork among the DEFENDANTS and LAWYERS as they turn to their copies.  53.

This is the report which was written, approved and signed by all of you immediately after the event. In the written report, you all claim you didn’t even know about the fire until after it happened. But that isn’t true, is it? The JUDGE waits.
Well? It isn’t true.
I don’t know what you’re asking.
The first thing I’m asking is, why didn’t you unlock the doors? HANNA takes a look to the other DEFENDANTS. For the first time her poise is crumbling.
Obviously. For the obvious reason. We couldn’t.
Why? Why couldn’t you?
We were guards. Our job was to guard the prisoners. We couldn’t just let them escape.
I see. And if they escaped, then you'd be blamed, you’d be charged, you might even be executed?
No.
Well then? The JUDGE waits.
If we opened the doors, then there would have been chaos. How could we have restored order? (MORE )

HANNA (cont'd) It happened so fast. It was snowing. The bombs - There were flames all over the village. Then the screaming began. It got worse and worse. And if they’d all come rushing out, we couldn’t just let them escape. We couldn’t. We were responsible for them.
So you did know what was happening? You did know? You made a choice. You let them die rather than risk letting them escape. HANNA can’t answer - she has no answer.
The other defendants have made an allegation against you. Have you heard this allegation? HANNA does not reply.
They say you were in charge.
It isn’t true. I was just one of the guards. The other DEFENDANTS interrupt to call out ‘She was in charge’.
Did you write the report?
No. No. We all discussed what to say. We all wrote it together.
She wrote it! She wrote the report. She was in charge.
Is that true?
No. And I didn’t write the report. Does it matter who did? RITA BECKHART has called out from her place. The JUDGE lo at HANNA a moment.  55.
I need to see a sample of your handwriting.
My handwriting?
Yes. I need to establish who wrote the report. At once HANNA’S COUNSEL rises.
I’m sorry, but I really don’t see how that’s appropriate. Nearly twenty years have gone by.
Somebody take her this piece of paper.
Are you really going to compare handwriting of twenty years ago, with handwriting of today?

Give her the paper. Counsel, approach the bench. A piece of paper and a pen are put down in front of HANNA Her COUNSEL moves to the bench. MICHAEL stares, first at then at the pen and paper, an apprehension rising in him.

MICHAEL thinks back, to HANNA in her bedroom saying ‘No y read’, to her looking puzzled at the menu on the bicycle trip, and to her throwing a book away in the apartment. A this moment, MICHAEL realises she is illiterate.
Back in the courtroom, HANNA looks up to the JUDGE to sto the conference.
There’s no need. I wrote the report.  56. MICHAEL, in a panic, pushes along his row, past ROHL and others, who all look up, knowing something is going on. H turns, as if sensing him behind her.

head_text.subj: INT. STAIRS. HEIDELBERG LAW SCHOOL. DAY

text: MICHAEL is sitting on the steps outside the lecture room. ROHL walks straight past him.
You’ve been skipping seminars.

head_text.subj: INT. LECTURE ROOM. HEIDELBERG LAW SCHOOL. DAY

text: MICHAEL comes into the room and sits down, smoking a cigarette. ROHL waits.
So? MICHAEL looks at him.
I have a piece of information. Concerning one of the defendants. Something they’re not admitting.
What information? MICHAEL stubs out his cigarette.
You don’t need me to tell you. It’s perfectly clear you have a moral obligation to disclose it to the court.
It happens this information is favourable to the defendant. It can help her case. It may even affect the outcome, certainly the sentencing.
So?
There’s a problem. The defendant herself is determined to keep this information secret.  57. Two STUDENTS come in for the seminar.
A moment, please. Please. Chastened, they leave.
What are her reasons?
Because she’s ashamed.
Ashamed? Ashamed of what? MICHAEL doesn’t answer.
Have you spoken to her?
Of course not.
Why of course not?
I can’t. I can’t do that. I can’t talk to her.
What we feel isn’t important. It’s utterly unimportant. The only question is what we do. ROHL gets up.
If people like you don’t learn from what happened to people like me, then what the hell is the point of anything?
HANNA is sitting on the edge of her bed. A GUARD comes to door.
You have a visitor. Michael Berg. HANNA is taken aback for a moment. Then she gets up.  58.

MICHAEL is standing smoking a cigarette in the waiting ar A whole number of visitors, old people, children, familie are waiting. Some kids are playing with a football. Then GUARD arrives and calls out names. MICHAEL’s name is call
HANNA is led swiftly down a prison corridor towards her meeting and sat down at a desk to wait.

MICHAEL is led in the GROUP towards the visiting room. It come on to snow. As he walks towards the room, he loses heart. He changes his mind. The rest of the GROUP go on, he falls behind, watching them go. He begins to turn back INT. MEETING ROOM. PRISON. DAY. HANNA sits down at the empty table, waiting.
MICHAEL turns away and heads back the way he came.
HANNA looks round. Nobody is coming. She waits more.
Time’s up.
HANNA is still waiting. Then she is led back to her cell. INT. MARTHE’S ROOM. STUDENT DIGS. NIGHT MICHAEL appears at the door of MARTHE’S room. She is work at her desk. He smiles and closes the door.

You’ve taken your time. They kiss. She starts to pull his clothes off. He lets he He makes no move to undress her. She takes all his clothe off until he is naked, and she remains clothed. He looks her a moment, then takes her in his arms and they go down the bed. They make love.  59. INT. MARTHE’S ROOM. NIGHT MARTHE is apparently asleep, MICHAEL awake. As quietly as can MICHAEL tries to slip away.
Where are you going?
I’m sorry. I need to sleep by myself.

HANNA is standing naked at the sink, preparing herself fo the day. INT. STUDENT DIGS. MICHAEL’S ROOM. DAWN MICHAEL is lying in his own bed, staring up at the ceilin not able to sleep. MICHAEL reluctantly pushes back the co and gets naked out of bed. Slowly he begins to dress.
HANNA washes herself, naked.
MICHAEL is dressed now. He stands in front of his mirror, adjusting his tie.
HANNA stands in front of the mirror, tying her tie. There a small, inadequate mirror in which she checks her dress black suit, a white blouse and black tie. She looks very formal.
HANNA is led through the prison by a GUARD.

A lot of people heading into the courtroom. As the semina group goes in, MICHAEL hangs back. ROHL looks at him as h goes through the doors. MICHAEL is left outside, then goe watch as the vans arrive.  60.
HANNA and the PRISONERS are led into the court. HANNA’S s is so formal that members of the public call out. ‘Nazi! Nazi!’ DIETER leans in to MARTHE. HANNA walks on to her place.
Everyone rises as the JUDGES come in to take their places HANNA’s face is resigned, without expression. The JUDGES The whole court goes quiet.

The court finds guilty the defendants Rita Beckhart, Karolina Steinhof, Regina Kreutz, Angela Zieber, Andrea Luhmann jointly aiding and abetting murder in three hundred cases. The court finds the defendant Hanna Schmitz guilty of murder in three hundred cases. There are tears in MICHAEL’s eyes as he watches.

The court sentences the accused as follows. Rita Beckhart, Karolina Steinhof, Regina Kreutz, Angela Zieber, and Andrea Luhmann, you will each serve a total sentence in prison of four years and three months. ROHL, MARTHE, DIETER and the students are looking down on sentencing. MICHAEL is crying.

Hanna Schmitz, in view of your own admissions and your special role, you are in a different category. The court sentences the accused Schmitz to imprisonment for life. HANNA is impassive, not reacting. Then she turns and look to the gallery.
MICHAEL walks away through the cameras and news crews.  61.
MICHAEL sits on the train, thinking. The younger MICHAEL becomes the older.
1976. MICHAEL is sitting beside JULIA. MICHAEL is 32, JUL is a bright little 4 year-old in a coat. The countryside speeding by.
Where are we going?
I said : I'll tell you when we get there. You told me you liked surprises.
I like surprises.
MICHAEL walks with JULIA towards their old house. He look round, the memory of coming with HANNA as a sick boy 18 y earlier clear in his mind. The same landmarks.

head_text.subj: INT. DINING ROOM. BERG APARTMENT. DAY

text: They are all three eating at the dinner table, eating a s roast chicken.
She’s grown, hasn’t she?
I don’t know. It’s so long since I saw her, Michael, how can I tell?
My fault. We shouldn’t have come unannounced.
Daddy, why’s she angry? MICHAEL smiles. Even CARLA smiles slightly.
I’m afraid I’ve have some bad news. Julia knows. (MORE )
MICHAEL (cont'd) We've already told her. Gertrud and I are getting a divorce.
Daddy’s going to live in his own house.
You didn’t come for your father’s funeral, but you come for this?
You know, it’s not easy for me to visit this town.
Were you really so unhappy?
That’s not what I’m saying. It’s not what I meant.
Well then? CARLA looks at him hard.
You mustn’t worry about Gertrud. I’m going to look after her. And anyway, let’s face it, she’s already a state prosecutor, she earns far more than I do.
Michael, I’m not worried about Gertrud. I’m worried about you.
Exhausted by her day, JULIA is sleeping in MICHAEL’S arms looks down at her, full of love.

On the other side of a busy Berlin street full of traffic MICHAEL holds JULIA’S hand, a loving father, to guide her across the street. INT. LANDING. GERTRUD’S APARTMENT. BERLIN. NIGHT GERTRUD has come to the door, a shrewd-looking intelligen woman, a little older than MICHAEL, very thin, in slacks a blouse. MICHAEL is standing outside with JULIA.  63.
Hello Mummy.
Hello beautiful. GERTRUD leans down and scoops JULIA up, kisses her. MICHA stands on the step, hovering.
Do you mind if I don’t ask you in?
I don’t mind at all. I’ve a lot to do, in fact. It doesn’t look like it. He stands, not going.
I took her to see where I grew up.
You went to the West? My God, what a trip.
We went to say hello to granny.
Oh. Daddy took you to see Carla, did he?
She was strange.
Come on, let’s see what’s on TV. GERTRUD gives JULIA her supper and puts her in front of t TV. Then she comes back to MICHAEL.
I bet she was strange.
You could say.
She always was. Why on earth did you decide to do that?
I don’t know. Impulse.  64. GERTRUD says nothing.
I suppose if I’m honest we went because I wanted to re-establish contact.
With your mother? And did you succeed? They both smile.
Are you all right? He touches her arm.
Michael you’re meant to be an intelligent man. Don’t you know, it’s very hard to receive contact if you’re not willing to give it? GERTRUD looks level, not unkind.
Say goodbye to Julia.

Goodbye, Daddy. MICHAEL turns to say goodbye. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. NIGHT MICHAEL standing in the empty room. It’s eerily silent. H goes to his bookcase. He runs his fingers along the spine as HANNA once did. He takes out a paperback of the Odysse He looks at it a moment, then he starts to read to himsel

“Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy... He sits back.  65. INT. HANNA’S CELL. DAWN HANNA is in her cell, folding her blanket. She is 53, a n austerity, a greyness about her. Her cell is modern, but without decoration.
A GUARD comes along the corridor, calling out ‘Mail’. She leans into Hanna’s cell to tell her she has mail. HANNA i obviously surprised.
HANNA reports to the mail room where she is given a big parcel, which she is told to open. Inside, a huge batch o casette tapes and a tape machine.
HANNA is opening the box, taking out the tapes. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL gets out a tape machine.
In her cell HANNA takes out the machine. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL holds the microphone.
Testing. Testing. 1-2-3.
HANNA puts a cassette into the machine.
The Odyssey by Homer. In panic, she turns it off. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL presses the recording button and speaks into the machine.  66.

The Odyssey by Homer. “Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy... Many cities of men he saw and learned their minds, Many pains he suffered, heartsick at the open sea, Fighting to save his life and bring his comrades home... INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT Later. MICHAEL is now walking up and down, in his shorts T-shirt, microphone in hand, still reading.
“Ah, how shameless - the way these mortals blame the gods. From us alone, they say, come all their miseries...
Middle of the night. MICHAEL is lying on his back, still reading.
“Who are you? Where are you from? Your city? Your parents? I’m wonderstruck - you drank my drugs, you're not bewitched...”

MICHAEL takes a cassette and puts it into a white box. He writes on the side ODYSSEY 6. Then he reaches up to put i a shelf next to boxes separately marked ODYSSEY 1,2,3,4,5 Then he takes out a small notebook and cross-references t new tape in a handwritten list.
It’s dark. HANNA is lying on the bed.
Zeus from the very start, the thunder king Has hated the race of Atreus with a vengeance -— (MORE )
MICHAEL'S VOICE (cont'd) His trustiest weapon women’s twisted wiles... HANNA smiles with pleasure at his reading.

A montage of MICHAEL reading and HANNA listening. MICHAEL reading different books. He is animated now, excited. The are extracts from The Old Man and the Sea (Hemingway) ; Anatol (Schnitzler) ; The World of Yesterday (Zweig) and Doctor Zhivago (Pasternak). MICHAEL catching fire with excitement with what he is doing. HANNA collecting the ta from the mail room and organizing on her shelves - her library growing.
HANNA is lying in bed listening to a new tape.
The Lady with the Little Dog, by Anton Chekhov. “The talk was that a new face had appeared on the promenade, a lady with a little dog...”
HANNA is walking round with other PRISONERS, in sequence. Suddenly she stops dead, an idea hitting her.
The library is right next to the mail room. HANNA walks p the mail room and goes to the library counter.
I want to take out a book.
Which book?
Do you have The Lady with the Little Dog?
What’s your name?
Hanna Schmitz.  68. The LIBRARIAN goes to get it. HANNA stands, waiting and l at the stacks of books, for the first time seeing possibility.
HANNA is back in the cell. She puts down a new parcel and book. She puts the parcel to one side, then opens the boo She then winds back the tape which is already in the recorder.

The Lady with the Little Dog, a story by Anton Chekhov. The talk was... She turns off the tape. She runs her finger along the tit ‘The Lady with the Little Dog’. She gets down a small decorated metal tin, and takes a pencil from it. She star making the sounds. ‘The’, ‘the’, ‘the’... L, L, L, etc.

HANNA is working now, circling the word ‘the’ each time i comes in the book. The book is covered in marks. EXT & INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE 1981. MICHAEL is coming down a busy Kreuzberg street. He 37. He goes into his block. He opens the door : the place much more lived-in. He picks up his mail. Thumbing throug it, he sees a letter in childish handwriting. MICHAEL fro opening it and taking out a piece of paper. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL is holding a letter. He looks down at the writing ‘Thanks for the latest, kid. I really liked it.’ He stare then puts it down and steps back stunned.

HANNA stands with a new package. She opens it excitedly. takes out tapes. She looks for writing, a letter. There i none. She turns the packing paper over and over, but ther nothing. She stands, desolate.
HANNA effortfully writing various letters - just a single message on each. The pen working agonizingly across the paper. First :  69.

head_text.subj: I WOULD LIKE MORE ROMANCE, LESS ADVENTURE

text: Next:

head_text.subj: I AM NOT SURE WHAT KAFKA IS SAYING

text: INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. BEDROOM. NIGHT MICHAEL continuing to read to her on the machine.
HANNA still writing.
Then finally, many attempts at the same sentence, written many times :

INT. STUDY. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL is reading the latest letter from HANNA. He looks it. “Do you receive my letters? Write to me, kid.” MICHAE opens a drawer in a file box on the floor. There is a sta of her letters inside. He puts the latest on top of the p and closes the drawer.
HANNA stands at her window, in despair. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY 1988. MICHAEL, 44, is at his desk, with the phone in his hand, with a typed letter in front of him.
You’re Michael Berg?
Yes.
You got my letter?
I have it here.
As I say, Hanna Schmitz is coming up for release very soon.  70. MICHAEL fingers the letter a moment. INT. BRENNER’S OFFICE. PRISON. DAY MS BRENNER is sitting at her desk in a simple, modern off

Hanna has been in prison for over twenty years. She has no family. She has no friends. You’re her only contact. And I’m told you don’t visit her. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY MICHAEL is sitting quite still.
No. I don’t. INT. BRENNER’S OFFICE. DAY
When she gets out, she’s going to need a job. She’s going to need somewhere to live. You can’t imagine how frightening the modern world will seem to her. There is a silence.
Yes. I’m still here. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY
I have no-one else to ask. If you don’t take responsibility for her, then Hanna has no future at all.

It’s kind of you. Thank you for letting me know. MICHAEL puts the phone down. He looks as if he has just b handed a sentence. He gets up and stares at the wall whic now stacked with all the books he has read. Then he goes his balcony. EXT & INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY MICHAEL stands looking out over Berlin from his balcony.  71.
MICHAEL walks along the road by the prison wall, then goe the guichet to sign in.
MICHAEL is waiting in a small barred waiting area as MS BRENNER walks across the yard to open the gate and let MICHAEL in.
You’re Michael Berg?
Yes.
Louisa Brenner. We were expecting you earlier.
MS BRENNER is walking MICHAEL up the steps towards the pr canteen. They pass GUARDS and INMATES.
I should warn you: for a long time Hanna held herself together. She was very purposeful. In the last few years she’s different. She’s let herself go.
MS BRENNER leads MICHAEL to the door of the canteen.

They’re in the canteen. They’re just finishing lunch. MICHAEL sees an OLD WOMAN who is sitting at a table. Her dress is stretched too tight across her heavy body. Her h is grey. She has a book in her lap, but she’s not reading A few PRISONERS are finishing their meal. It takes MICHAEL a moment to realise the OLD WOMAN is HAN Then HANNA becomes aware of being watched. She turns and looks round. At once her face lights up. MICHAEL smiles b but as he approaches her, he fixes onto her inquiring loo and sees the light go out of her eyes, as if she has look at him and been disappointed. He sits down opposite her. smiles, weary.  72.
You’ve grown up, kid. She takes his hand. There is a long silence, MICHAEL unab to think of anything to say. He withdraws his hand.
I’ve got a friend who's a tailor, he makes my suits. He’ll give you a job. And I’ve found you somewhere to live. It’s a nice place. Quite small but nice. I think you’1l like it.
Thank you. There’s a moment’s silence.
There are various social programmes, cultural stuff I can sign you up for. And there’s a public library very close. HANNA nods slightly.
You read a lot?
I prefer being read to. There is a short silence.
That’s over now, isn’t it? MICHAEL doesn’t answer.
Did you get married?
I did. Yes I did. We have a daughter. I’m not seeing as much of her as I would like. I’d like to see a great deal more of her. After a few moments, he concedes.
The marriage didn’t last.  73. There is a silence.
Have you spent a lot of time thinking about the past?
You mean, with you?
No. No, I didn’t mean with me.
Before the trial I never thought about the past. I never had to.
And now? What do you feel now? HANNA looks a moment, a haunting look, searching him. There’s a
It doesn’t matter what I think. It doesn’t matter what I feel. The dead are still dead. silence.
I wasn’t sure what you’d learnt.
I have learnt, kid. I’ve learnt to read. MICHAEL stares, devastated.
I‘1ll pick you up next week, OK?
That sounds a good plan.
Good. Quietly, or shall we make a big fuss?
Quietly.
OK. Quietly.  74. They look at each other. The other PRISONERS have already gone. They stand up. She scans his face again, searching his thoughts. He takes her in his arms, a little awkward.
Take care, kid.
You too. They walk side by side, back towards the door. Then by wa saying goodbye, she takes his hand.
See you next week. She stretches her arm out before she lets go of his hand, then vanishes inside. MICHAEL walks on alone.

MICHAEL comes out of the main entrance. He stands a momen looking round at the evening. MICHAEL walks to his car. INT. HANNA’S ROOM. EVE The room is simple, a bedroom to one side, a bathroom to other. It is all furnished with simple functional furnitu The end of a hard day’s work. MICHAEL hangs a picture ove the desk - a landscape, reminiscent of where they once we cycling. The job is done. He looks round, grimly content.

HANNA is lying on her bed, fully dressed. She gets up and gets some books down from the shelf. She puts them, one b one, in a pile on the table. Then she takes off her shoes She stands up and climbs onto the pile of books on the ta Her bare feet on the books. Then she reaches up.
MICHAEL gets out of the car. He is carrying a bunch of flowers. He walks towards the prison. He leans in to the GUARD who is in a modern office.
From the far end of the corridor, MICHAEL is seen sitting a bench. MS BRENNER comes out of her office and murmurs i his ear. MICHAEL is seen nodding, ashen.  75.

The two of them come together down the corridor. They sto the open door of the cell. The body has been removed. The books are still on the floor. MICHAEL goes in. A bare tab a chair, a bed, a closet, a toilet in the corner behind t door. There are shelves with books, an alarm clock, a stu bear, two mugs, instant coffee, tea tins.

She didn’t pack. She never intended to leave. MS BRENNER looks at him in confirmation. MICHAEL looks at two lower shelves on which are ranged the tapes with the cassette machine. Above the bed are a series of cuttings, pictures torn fro magazines, showing meadows, hillsides, pasture, cherry tr One in particular : a burst of autumnal colours. MICHAEL kneels on the bed to look at them. There are quotations, articles, recipes, even sayings in HANNA’S childish handwriting : ‘Spring lets its blue banner flutter throug the air’ is one. Then he sees a newspaper photograph : th young MICHAEL BERG receiving a prize from the school principal. The headline ‘Michael Berg receives school literature prize.’ MS BRENNER reaches out for a tea tin from the shelf. Then sits next to MICHAEL on the bed, and takes out a folded s of paper from her suit pocket.
She left me a message, a sort of will. I’11 read out the bit that concerns you. MICHAEL looks at the effortful handwriting on the page.

“There is money in the old tea tin. Give it to Michael Berg. He should send it, alongside the 7,000 marks in the bank, to the daughter who wrote the book. It’s for her. She should decide what to do with it. And tell Michael I said hello. Tell him to get on with his life.” MS BRENNER looks at him.
Do you want to see her?  76. MICHAEL shakes his head.
MICHAEL rides in a taxi into Manhattan. A view of the familiar skyline.

MICHAEL'S taxi comes up Fifth Avenue. It draws up outside expensive apartment block. MICHAEL gets out and goes in, Manhattan skyline opening up behind him. INT. LIVING ROOM. ILANA’S APARTMENT. DAY A superbly appointed space full of great and expensive ar MICHAEL has taken his coat off. ILANA MATHER appears, elegant, well-dressed - on the surface, the spirit of prosperous New York. She is now in her early fifties.
Ms Mather?
Yes. You’re Michael Berg. I was expecting you.
So you must tell me: what exactly brings you to the United States?
I was already here. I was at a conference in Boston.
You're a lawyer?
Yes.
I was intrigued by your letter but I can’t say I wholly understood it. You attended the trial?
Yes. Almost twenty years ago. I was a law student. I remember you, I remember your mother very clearly.  77.
My mother died in Israel - a good many years ago.
I’m sorry. MICHAEL hesitates for a moment.
Go on, please.
Perhaps you heard. Hanna Schmitz recently died. She killed herself. ILANA shakes her head.
She was a friend of yours?
A kind of friend. It’s as simple as this. Hanna was illiterate for the greater part of her life.
Is that an explanation of her behaviour?
No.
Or an excuse? MICHAEL shakes his head.
No. No. She taught herself to read when she was in prison. I sent her tapes. She’d always liked being read to. ILANA shifts slightly.
Why don’t you start by being honest with me? At least start that way. What was the nature of your friendship?
When I was young I had an affair with Hanna. ILANA looks at him for a moment.
I’m not sure I can help you, Mr. Berg. Or rather, even if I could I’m not willing to.
I was almost sixteen when I took up with her. The affair only lasted a summer. But.
But what? MICHAEL just looks at her.
I see. And did Hanna Schmitz acknowledge the effect she’d had on your life? MICHAEL stares back, understood for the first time.
She'd done much worse to other people. I’ve never told anyone.

People ask all the time what I learned in the camps. But the camps weren’t therapy. What do you think these places were? Universities? We didn’t go there to learn. One becomes very clear about these things. ILANA looks at him, unrelenting.

What are you asking for? Forgiveness for her? Or do you just want to feel better yourself? My advice, go to the theatre, if you want catharsis. Please. Go to literature. Don't go to the camps. Nothing comes out of the camps. Nothing. 78.  79. ILANA looks at him, unrelenting.
What she wanted...what she wanted was to leave you her money. I have with me.
To do what?
As you think fit. MICHAEL reaches for his briefcase. He takes out the laven tea-tin, which he sets down on the table in front of ILAN
Here. ILANA lifts the tin.
When I was a little girl, I hada tea-tin for my treasures. Not quite like this. It had Cyrillic lettering. I took it with me to the camp, but it got stolen.
What was in it?

Oh. Sentimental things. A piece of hair from our dog. Some tickets to operas my father had taken me to. It wasn’t stolen for its contents. It was the tin itself which was valuable, what you could do with it. She sits a moment, overcome, her hand on the tin.

There’s nothing I can do with this money. If I give it to anything associated with the extermination of the Jews, then to me it will seem like absolution and that is something I’m neither willing nor in a position to grant. MICHAEL nods slightly.  80.
I was thinking maybe an organization to encourage literacy.
Good. There’s a silence.
Good.
Do you know if there’s a Jewish organization?
I‘ll be surprised if there isn’t. There’s a Jewish organisation for everything. Not that illiteracy is a very Jewish problem. There is the shadow of a smile.
Why don’t you find out? Send them the money.
Shall I do it in Hanna’s name?
As you think fit. ILANA smiles slightly. She puts her hand on top of the ti

I‘ll keep the tin. INT. ILANA’S HOUSE. DAY ILANA is standing at the window watching down to the stre where MICHAEL is walking away. She has the tin in her han When he’s vanished, she turns and goes into her bedroom. There on the dressing table, there is a framed photo of I with her mother in Germany before the war. She sets the t down beside the photo.
1995. MICHAEL is driving JULIA in the big Mercedes throug the German countryside. He is tense, silent. JULIA takes sideways look at him, but he does not respond.  81.
Where are we going?
I thought you liked surprises.
I do. I do like surprises.
They draw up at a church. It is the same one he and HANNA passed on their bicycles years before. MICHAEL and JULIA out and walk towards the graveyard at the side.
MICHAEL & JULIA stand at a deserted grave-side. The whole cemetery is seen. MICHAEL stoops down and uncovers a simp stone : HANNA SCHMITZ 1923-1988. JULIA watching, says her name.
Hanna Schmitz. JULIA waits a moment.
Who was she?
That’s what I wanted to tell you. That’s why we're here. JULIA looks, waiting. MICHAEL looks for a moment as if he will not go on.
So tell me. There is a moment, then they turn to stroll, MICHAEL talk starting to tell the story.
I was 15, I was coming home from school, I was ill... They walk away among the trees.
